nodes.description: Jeremy Corbyn attended the public vigil in Manchester to remember the 22 people killed in the terror attack.
nodes.support_text: Jeremy Corbyn attended the huge public vigil in Manchester last night as the city gathered to remember the 22 people killed in Monday’s terror attack.

nodes.description: The vigil was held hours before Theresa May raised the terror threat level to 'critical'.
nodes.support_text: The gathering was held hours before Theresa May raised the terror threat level to “critical”, the highest band.

nodes.description: Jeremy Corbyn recorded a video message expressing sympathy for the victims and determination to resist terrorism.
nodes.support_text: Yesterday Corbyn recorded a video message saying Britain was “united in sympathy” for the victims of an “horrific atrocity”.

nodes.description: Tony Lloyd emphasized that the city would not be divided by evil acts and would overcome the tragedy.
nodes.support_text: Tony Lloyd, the former police and crime commissioner, said “evil acts” would not be allowed to divide the city.

nodes.description: The Labour leader joined Andy Burnham, the new metro mayor, Amber Rudd, the home secretary, and John Bercow, alongside senior figures from the police, and thousands of local residents at the event.
nodes.support_text: The Labour leader joined Andy Burnham, the new metro mayor, Amber Rudd, the home secretary, and John Bercow alongside senior figures from the police, and thousands of local residents.

nodes.description: Sunshine bathed the sombre crowd as it held a minute’s silence while people many remained in Albert Square long after the event had formally closed.
nodes.support_text: Sunshine bathed the sombre crowd as it held a minute’s silence while people many remained in Albert Square long after the event had formally closed.

nodes.description: The authorities express determination that terrorism will not determine communities and that the poison of terror will not pollute democratic politics.
nodes.support_text: We are determined that terrorism will not determine our communities as the perpetrators clearly intended. We are determined that the poison of terror will not be allowed to pollute our democratic politics.

nodes.description: The authorities emphasize that the Manchester arena attack will not go further.
nodes.support_text: Murderous hatred visited on the Manchester arena – it will go no further.

nodes.description: Simon Danczuk has been barred from taking part under party colours in Rochdale.
nodes.support_text: Simon Danczuk has been barred from taking part under party colours in Rochdale where Lloyd will stand for Labour.

nodes.description: Tony Lloyd emphasized that the city would not be divided by evil acts and would overcome the tragedy.
nodes.support_text: Tony Lloyd, who will stand for Labour in Rochdale where Simon Danczuk has been barred taking part under party colours, said: “We’ll get through this because that is the spirit of Manchester.”

edges.support_text: The gathering was held hours before Theresa May raised the terror threat level to “critical”, the highest band.
The authorities express determination that terrorism will not determine communities and that the poison of terror will not pollute democratic politics.
Yesterday Corbyn recorded a video message saying Britain was “united in sympathy” for the victims of an “horrific atrocity”.
Tony Lloyd, the former police and crime commissioner, said “evil acts” would not be allowed to divide the city.
Sunshine bathed the sombre crowd as it held a minute’s silence while people many remained in Albert Square long after the event had formally closed.
The authorities emphasize that the Manchester arena attack will not go further.
Tony Lloyd, who will stand for Labour in Rochdale where Simon Danczuk has been barred taking part under party colours, said: “We’ll get through this because that is the spirit of Manchester.”
